intro: Galium mollugo f. pycnotrichum, commonly known as the hairy bedstraw, is a low-growing perennial plant belonging to the Rubiaceae family. It is characterized by its prostrate or ascending stems that are densely covered with short, glandular hairs. The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers clustered in cymes, typically blooming from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often have a hairy texture, contributing to its distinctive appearance. This variant is adapted to moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodland areas or along stream banks.
